discussion.content:
Correct answer is C.
Only AGGREGATE interface can belong to a zone.

MGT and HA interface cannot be assigned to zones

comments.content: you cannot put the HA or management interfaces into a zone.

questions.question_text: Which security policy rule would be needed to match traffic that passes between the Outside zone and Inside zone, but does not match traffic that passes within the zones?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct answer.interzone matches traffic btw outside and inside zone but does not match traffic within zone while universal matches traffic btw inside and outside and also within zones

Selected Answer: B
interzone

Interzone

universal match between inside and outside then within inside and outside to while Interzone match only between inside and outside zone.
answer is B

Answer should be D, and here is why:
The precedence is from the top down; First Match Wins: 1) Block list: Manually entered blocked URLs Objects - 2) Allow list: Manually entered allowed URLs Objects - 3) Custom URL Categories - 4) Cached Cached: URLs learned from External Dynamic Lists (EDLs) - 5) Pre-Defined Categories: PAN-DB or Brightcloud categories.

comments.content:
Check out the wording of the question:
"....and each could be used to block access to a specific URL.....which choice would be the last to block access to the URL?"

ALL options will block the URLs, it's asking here about the order of blocking, which will be first or last to block, it's not asking IF those options would block or not ;)
The answer is of course D
1- Block list
2- Allow list
3- Custom URL Cat.
4- EDLs
5- Downloaded PAN-DB Files
6- PAN-DB Cloud
Option C could block as well but would be the FIRST thing to block.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
When you configure a URL category directly in a security rule as match criteria, that will be analyzed before all security profiles, including URL-Filtering. 

Within URL-Filtering, custom categories are analyzed first, then EDLs, then pre-defined categories. So the answer must be D.

The precedence is from the top down; First Match Wins:
 1) Block list: Manually entered blocked URLs Objects 
 2) Allow list: Manually entered allowed URLs Objects - 
3) Custom URL Categories - 
4) Cached Cached: URLs learned from External Dynamic Lists (EDLs) -
 5) Pre-Defined Categories: PAN-DB or Brightcloud categories.

Selected Answer: D
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClyTCAS

The order in which the device checks for URL categories is as follows:

 Block list
 Allow list
 Custom categories
 Device cache
 BrightCloud downloaded database
 Cloud lookup (if enabled

Selected Answer: D
I think D is the most accurate according to this topic
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClyTCAS

I think A is correct answer.

In earlier release versions, URL Filtering category overrides had priority enforcement ahead of custom URL categories. As part of the upgrade to PAN-OS 9.0, URL category overrides are converted to custom URL categories, and no longer receive priority enforcement over other custom URL categories. Instead of the action you defined for the category override in previous release versions, the new custom URL category is enforced by the security policy rule with the strictest URL Filtering profile action. From most strict to least strict, possible URL Filtering profile actions are: block, override, continue, alert, and allow.
In my oppinion the correct answer is D. See also question 59.
why not D? I think the correct answer should be D
I think it is B

Answer should be B, and here is why:
The precedence is from the top down; First Match Wins: 1) Block list: Manually entered blocked URLs Objects - 2) Allow list: Manually entered allowed URLs Objects - 3) Custom URL Categories - 4) Cached Cached: URLs learned from External Dynamic Lists (EDLs) - 5) Pre-Defined Categories: PAN-DB or Brightcloud categories.
If it matches all possible options then the last match would technically be the first match.
This cannot be C because it has to do with URL filtering and therefore would be part of a security profile not policy.

questions.question_text: Four configuration choices are listed, and each could be used to block access to a specific URL. If you configured each choice to block the same URL then which choice would be the last to block access to the URL?

choices.C: Custom URL category in Security policy rule
choices.D: PAN-DB URL category in URL Filtering Profile
choices.B: Custom URL category in URL Filtering Profile

questions.question_text: Which data flow direction is protected in a zero-trust firewall deployment that is not protected in a perimeter-only firewall deployment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
It should be D. Zero-trust protects all traffic no matter the direction including east-west. But that's not the case with Perimeter-only where east-west is not covered.

Selected Answer: D
• Inspect perimeter traffic: Inbound traffic and Outbound traffic
• Also inspect internal traffic (east-west)
[Palo Alto Networks].
[Palo Alto Networks]

Selected Answer: D
answer is D ease/west

answe is D ease/west
